did.abstract: Augustus Freeman Hawkins (1907- ) was a member of the California State Assembly (1935-63) a Democrat in the U.S. Congress (1963-91), Chairman of the Committee on House Administration (1981-84), Chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor (98th-101st Congresses), and a member of many Congressional Committees. He retired from public service in 1990. The collection consists of materials documenting Hawkins' service as a U.S. Congressman from 1963-90 and as Chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee from 1984-90. A small portion of the collection relates to his service as a California State Assemblyman.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Augustus Freeman Hawkins was born in Shreveport, Louisiana, on August 31, 1907; his family moved to Los Angeles in 1918; AB, UCLA, 1931; graduated from USC, 1932; member, California State Assembly, 1935-63; Democrat, U.S. Congress, 1963-91; Chairman, Committee on House Administration, 1981-84; Chairman, Committee on Education and Labor (98th-101st Congresses); member, Joint Economic Committee, 1984-90; member, Joint Committee on Printing, 1977-84; member, Joint Committee on the Library, 1981-84; retired from public service in 1990.

bioghist.head: Biographical Narrative
bioghist.p: Augustus F. Hawkins was born August 31, 1907, in Shreveport, Louisiana. At age eleven his family moved to Los Angeles, California, where he later attended Jefferson High School, graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles with a degree in Economics, and attended graduate school at the University of Southern California.

Congressman Hawkins represented south, central Los Angeles for fifty-six years. He served from 1935 to 1962 in the California State Assembly before coming to Washington in 1963 as a member of the United States House of Representatives. He will retire from elected public service at the end of 1990.

He has compiled a remarkable record of legislative achievement. As a State Assemblyman he authored over 100 laws, including many important social welfare and anti-discrimination bills. As a United States Congressman, he has enacted legislation in the areas of child care; elementary, secondary, vocational and higher education; job training and employment; and Civil Rights. Significant bills passed into public law include the Civil Rights Act Amendment establishing the Equal Employment opportunity Commission, 1975; the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act Amendments, 1978; the Full Employment and Balanced Growth (Humphrey-Hawkins) Act, 1978; the Job Training partnership Act, 1982; the School Improvement (Hawkins-Stafford) Act, 1988; and the Civil Rights Restoration Act, 1988.

Prior to his chairmanship of the Education and Labor Committee, Congressman Hawkins served as chairman of the House Administration Committee from 1981 to 1984, where he was responsible for House of Representatives procurement, personnel, printing, elections, and automation issues. Additionally, he served as a member of the Joint Economic Committee from 1984 to 1990, the Joint Committee on Printing from 1977 to 1984, and the Joint Committee on the Library from 1981 to 1984.

Congressman Hawkins' view of public service is best expressed by his own words: The leadership belongs not to the loudest, not to those who beat the drums or blow the trumpets, but to those who day in and day out, in all seasons, work for the practical realization of a better world --those who have the stamina to persist and to remain dedicated. To those belong the leadership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of materials documenting Augustus F. Hawkins's lengthy service as a U.S. Congressman representing South Central Los Angeles from 1963-90 and as Chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee from 1984-90. A small portion of the collection relates to his service as a California State Assemblyman, 1935-62. Materials in the collection cover subjects such as Civil Rights, employment, child care, and equal opportunity with respect to education and job training.

scopecontent.head: Expanded Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The papers of Congressman Augustus F. Hawkins include materials documenting his lengthy service as an United States Congressman representing south, central Los Angeles from 1963 to 1990 and as the Chairman of the Education and Labor Committee from 1984 to 1990. A small amount of material relates to his service as a California state Assemblyman from 1935 to 1962.

In the collection are Legislative Files, Subject Files, Correspondence Files, District Office Files, Education and Labor Committee Files, California State Assembly Files, and Miscellaneous Material. The papers cover subjects such as civil rights, employment, equal opportunity, education, job training, and child care. The two series with perhaps the greatest research value are the legislative files since they document Congressman Hawkins' attempts to enact legislation and his Committee service, and the subject files which provide the background information, including his handwritten notes, for many of his legislative efforts.

During the last year, approximately 200 boxes of inactive files of the Washington and district offices and numerous filing cabinets and boxes of Education and Labor Committee staff files were reviewed to determine historical value. Of this total, over 130 boxes were retained for the archives. Duplicates, publications, routine files, and other materials were discarded.

The papers are arranged by series (or type). A minimum amount of arrangement was done within each series. Each type of material is described in a series description (a narrative with accompanying box lists or box and folder lists). Individual folder listings were compiled for most of the series and were taken directly from folder labels. The number in parentheses after a folder listing indicates when more than one folder exists for a particular topic. Since similar materials could not always be packed together, numbered boxes are sometimes listed out of order. Asterisks denote when a box containing more than one type of material appears on the list more than once. Additionally, box counts given at the beginning of each series are not the actual number of boxes in that series but rather a total of the number of boxes containing that type of material. The table of contents below refers researchers to individual series descriptions.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Legislative files (39 Boxes).
Subject files (31 Boxes).
Correspondence files (10 Boxes).
District office files (39 Boxes).
Education and Labor Committee files (17 Boxes).
California State Assembly files (2 Boxes).
Miscellaneous (11 Boxes).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included in the Legislative Files are lists of bills sponsored and cosponsored by Congressman Hawkins, bill files, Committee files, and a few subject files. Preceding the bill files are bill listings compiled by office staff and staff of the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress. For the 88th through 92nd Congresses, there are pages from the gongressional Record Index which list where in the Record to find information about bills and resolutions introduced by the Congressman. The CRS listings, beginning with the 93rd Congress, describe the bill and any action taken. Additionally, there are CRS listings found within each Congress that may duplicate information found at the beginning of the series.

In most cases, the actual bill files simply contain a copy of the bill or resolution. A few other bill files also contain related materials such as bill drafts, companion and related bills from the House and Senate, Committee reports, floor statements, press releases, dear colleague and other letters from members of Congress, correspondence from constituents and others interested in legislation, analyses of bills, newsclippings, memos, and other types of material. Interestingly, in the bill files concerning Watergate, all of the constituent correspondence supports impeaching President Richard Nixon. It is unclear if the Hawkins office received any constituent correspondence supporting the former President.

Committee files primarily include correspondence from constituents and others on legislative matters before Committees. Also included are dear colleague and other letters from members to Congressman Hawkins, Committee reports, bills, memos, press releases, floor statements, Committee agenda, bill drafts, newsclippings, Committee testimony, and hearing reports. Miscellaneous Committee files contain correspondence about Senate bills, House bills not yet under consideration, and issues for which there was no pending legislation.

The Education and Labor Committee files contain constituent correspondence; correspondence from other members of Congress, state and local officials, and others with an interest in legislation; bills; Committee reports; lists of activities of members of the Committee; summaries of major legislative actions of the Committee; copies of letters and memos to and from former Chairman Carl Perkins; floor statements; staff memos to Chairman Hawkins; Committee testimony; bill analyses; floor remarks; newsclippings; lists of Committee members; and other materials. Materials documenting Congressman Hawkins chairmanship of the Equal Opportunities SubCommittee from 1977 to 1984, include correspondence from him to other subCommittee members, hearing reports, minutes of mark-up sessions, lists of witnesses, press releases, and weekly and monthly reports during the 94th Congress.

A few subject files are found throughout this series. The largest and most notable group are found within the 93rd Congress and concern legislation sponsored by Congressman Hawkins to rectify a 1906 Brownsville, Texas incident where approximately 170 black soldiers, blamed by townspeople for a local crime, were dishonorably discharged from the army without evidence to prove their guilt and without a trial. Congressman Hawkins' bill changed the military record of each man to reflect an honorable discharge and provided compensation to any living survivors or their widows. These files contain bills; background material; a Senate bill and report; drafts of legislation; correspondence between members of Congress; Congressman Hawkins' correspondence with the Army Department and Veterans Administration, widows of servicemen, the media, and John Weaver, the author of a book on the subject; press releases; floor statements; newsclippings; and other materials.

At the end of the files for the 99th Congress are a few miscellaneous Committee files documenting the work of the House Administration Committee, of which Congressman Hawkins was chair from 1981 to 1984, and two other panels he belonged to -- the Joint Committee on the Library and the Joint Committee on Printing.

The Legislative Files were found broadly arranged by term of Congress. within each term of Congress, the bill files were separated into bills sponsored and cosponsored and within each, the files were either alphabetical by bill title or numerical by bill number. The Committee files were generally alphabetical by name of Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Subject Files primarily contain background material on issues such as Civil Rights, equal employment and affirmative action, full employment, and employment training. Additionally, there are materials that document the work of the Congressional Black Caucus and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Included are notes, reports prepared by Committees and government agencies, magazine and newspaper clippings, correspondence from various groups, press releases, bills and resolutions, reference material, Committee testimony, comparative analyses of bills, memos, witness lists, correspondence between Congressman Hawkins and other members of Congress, floor statements, new releases and newsletters from various groups, action and Meeting agendas, and membership lists.

Documented in the Civil Rights and jobs subject files is Congressman Hawkins' work as chairman of the SubCommittee on Employment Opportunities in the late 1970s. In the EEOC files are materials pertaining to a study in 1974 of state bar association practices with regard to testing and admittance of minority candidates to the bar. Under full employment are materials relating to H.R. 50, the Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act of 1977 or the Humphrey-Hawkins Bill, as it came to be known, sponsored by Congressman Hawkins and Senator Hubert Humphrey. The employment and training files include materials concerning H.R. 1036, the Community Renewal Employment Act of 1983, the Job Training Partnership Act, the Comprehensive Education and Training Act, and other legislation. There are many loose materials, Unlabeled files, and publications and reports with notes in the margins under education and training. Included in the affirmative action files are materials relating to an investigation of charges of discrimination in the Los Angeles aerospace industry in 1970.
The Subject Files were found organized, in most cases, by broad subject area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included in the Correspondence Files are Computer Files, General Files, Executive Department and Agency Files, and a few other types of correspondence files all from 1978 forward. No correspondence was found pre-dating 1978.

In the Computer Files is constituent correspondence on legislative issues along with responses from the Congressman; however, only some of the 1987 files contain copies of Congressman Hawkins' responses. Listed on each letter are a sequence of numbers, with each number representing form paragraphs or text. The text file can be found in Box 126. The Computer Files are generally arranged by document number.

The General Files contain constituent correspondence on non-legislative matters and, in most cases, the Congressman's responses to those letters. Correspondence is filed by the last name of the letter writer in folders for each letter of the alphabet. There are a few subject files in some years of the General Files. Many of the routine subject files were disposed of during work on this series.

Executive Department and Agency Files primarily include correspondence between Congressman Hawkins and Cabinet secretaries and administrators of other government agencies. There are also letters from Congressman Hawkins and his colleagues to these agency officials, some constituent correspondence, correspondence between Congressman Hawkins and California state and local officials, and correspondence with White House officials. The White House file usually precedes the Executive Department Files, which are followed by the Agency Files. Within Executive Department and Agency Files, respectively, arrangement is alphabetical.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The District Office Files include Bill Files, Alphabetical Files, Subject Files, the Washington File, Correspondence Logs, Press Files, Academy Files, Pictures, and Miscellaneous Material. All files are from the Los Angeles district office except those in Boxes 107-111, which are from the Huntington Park office.

The Bill Files, 1963-76, 1981-88, contain bills sponsored and cosponsored by Congressman Hawkins and other bills not sponsored by him but that were referred to the Committee on Education and Labor. Occasionally, Committee reports and Senate companion bills are found is these files. The bill files are generally arranged by terms of Congress and in many cases the dates overlap from one group of bill files to another. Several of the groups of bill files are alphabetical by subject while others have no discernible order. No bill files from the 95th and 96th Congresses, 1977-80, were found.

There is correspondence in the Alphabetical Files, Subject Files, and Washington File that addresses general issues, usually non-legislative matters. No correspondence pre-dating 1972 was found. Alphabetical Files, 1973, 1977-88, contain only responses to correspondence addressed to the district office and are filed in the alphabetical folder corresponding to the last name of the letter writer. Written on each letter is the subject of the correspondence, which serves as a cross-reference to the Subject Files, 1963-89, where the incoming correspondence along with another copy of the response is found. Perhaps, the Alphabetical Files served as a quick reference to correspondence if the Washington office called with a question or the correspondent phoned or visited the office. In the Subject Files is correspondence extending invitations, addressing legislative concerns, seeking endorsements or recommendations of programs in their quest for financial support, correspondence referred from other congressional offices or referred to the Congressman by his aides, requests for information, and other material. A large group of Subject Files, dated 1963 to 1975, are alphabetical by subject within this broad range of years, while the remainder, dated 1973 to 1989, are alphabetical by subject within each year.

The Washington File, 1972-73, 1977-88, duplicates correspondence found in Washington. The file contains yellow copies of responses to correspondence sent out by the Washington office and is important because the Washington office correspondence does not pre-date 1978. Arrangement is by subject for most of the Washington File. A small amount of correspondence for part of 1984 through 1987 is arranged in alphabetical files by the last name of the correspondent, and the 1988 Washington File is chronological [Other duplicate copies of correspondence which may be found in the Hawkins collection are pink copies sent to D.C. from the Los Angeles office and blue copies sent from the Huntington Park office to D.C.]. Correspondence Logs, 1983-89, record correspondence received by the district office, date received, subject, and name of correspondent.

In the Press Files, 1978-89 are columns and press releases issued by the Washington and district offices, drafts of releases and columns, Committee and subCommittee press releases, and miscellaneous releases issued by the Congressional Black Caucus, neighboring congressional district offices, and other groups. Congressman Hawkins' columns (opinion pieces) were issued weekly, his press releases less frequently. Both are filed in reverse chronological order.

Included in Academy Files, 1964-83, are files of individuals desiring admission into a military service academy and files documenting the review and selection of those persons that the Congressman nominated to academies. only the files of individuals actually admitted into an academy were retained.

Picture Files, ca. 1963-84, contain a wide variety of photographs, including pictures of town Meetings with the Congressman; photos from campaigns, ribbon cutting ceremonies, parades, and other events; and staff photos. There are photos from the President's signing of the Humphrey-Hawkins Employment Bill and a Hawkins'-sponsored minimum wage bill. The picture files are in no order (and some pictures are obviously misfiled). There are a number of empty, but labeled, folders that were retained in case those photos were found misfiled.

Miscellaneous Files, ca. 1934, 1948, 1953, and 1963-1985, contain primarily materials from the Congressman's congressional career but a few items pre-date 1963. Included are files documenting grant funding for projects such as the LA freeways; the political campaigns of Congressman Hawkins and other democrats; and the work of former district office aides Charles Knox, Bob Wilson, and Adam Burton. Also included are certificates and awards presented to the Congressman. In Box 67 are oversize photos and miscellaneous materials. The Miscellaneous Files are unorganized.

Finally, there are CCEDE (Coordinating Council on Economic Development and Employment) Files from 1963 to 1972. During this period Charles Knox, Congressman Hawkins' district office manager, served as a consultant to the council. Congressman Hawkins founded the CCEDE around 1961 to provide answers to many of the social problems of south, central Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Education and Labor Committee Files contain copies made from the files of staffers in key positions who have assisted Congressman Hawkins over the years. Several of the staff simply donated portions of their files for inclusion in the Hawkins papers. Subjects covered include equal Opportunity; Civil Rights; elementary, secondary, post secondary, and select education; budget; media relations; special projects; labor; employment and training; human resources; and child care.

In these files are correspondence, memos, speeches, press releases and columns, notes, testimony, hearing reports, bills, amendments, floor statements, Committee agenda, and other materials. -The official record of the Committee's activities can be found in the National Archives in Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The California State Assembly Files contain correspondence, legislative f iles, newsletters and press releases, political files, subject files, and other material documenting State Assemblyman Hawkins' career from 1935 to 1963 in the lower body of the state legislature. The files are generally arranged by year with only a few subject files, arranged alphabetically, within each year. At the beginning of the Assembly Files is a partial list of Congressman Hawkins' bills enacted into law.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included in Miscellaneous Material are the files of two former Hawkins staffers -- Annette Crumbley, Appointments Secretary/ Caseworker, and Juanita Barbee, Administrative Assistant. In Crumbley's files are invitations extended to the Congressman, correspondence from personal dictation taken by Crumbley, a few subject files, and other unfiled miscellaneous material. Barbee's files contain legislative correspondence, hearing reports, testimony, and bills; personal and public relations files; files concerning the educational research mission of the Hawkins Family Memorial Foundation; and other material.

There are speeches given by Congressman Hawkins between 1972 and 1974. Other speeches can be found in Saralee Todd's Education and Labor Committee Files and possibly interspersed throughout the Subject Files series. Additionally, there are mounted photographs and text from an exhibit at the California Museum of Science and Industry in 1982 entitled Blacks in the United States Congress, 1870-1981, and miscellaneous other items such as appointment books, correspondence, speeches, press files, and photographs that need interfiling in their appropriate series.
